body:
### Problem

When using neovim as a pager, nvim crashes when viewing man pages from `man`.

```sh
$ MANPAGER="nvim --clean --noplugin -" man man
E903: Process failed to start: permission denied: "/usr/local/bin/nvim"Failed to start Nvim server!
man: command exited with status 1: sed -e '/^[[:space:]]*$/{ N; /^[[:space:]]*\n[[:space:]]*$/D; }' | LESS=-ix8RmPm Manual page man(1) ?ltline %lt?L/%L.:byte %bB?s/%s..?e (END):?pB %pB\%.. (press h for help or q to quit)$PM Manual page man(1) ?ltline %lt?L/%L.:byte %bB?s/%s..?e (END):?pB %pB\%.. (press h for help or q to quit)$ MAN_PN=man(1) nvim --clean --noplugin -
```

However, it works when piping into neovim

```sh
# this works perfect!
$ MANPAGER=cat man man | nvim --clean --noplugin -
```

```sh
$ man --version
man 2.11.2


$ build/bin/nvim -V1 -v
NVIM v0.11.0-dev-714+g220b8aa6f
Build type: Debug
LuaJIT 2.1.1724512491
Compilation: /usr/bin/cc -g  -Wall -Wextra -pedantic -Wno-unused-parameter -Wstrict-prototypes -std=gnu99 -Wshadow -Wconversion -Wvla -Wdouble-promotion -Wmissing-noreturn -Wmissing-format-attribute -Wmissing-prototypes -fsigned-char -fstack-protector-strong -Wno-conversion -fno-common -Wimplicit-fallthrough -fdiagnostics-color=always  -DNVIM_LOG_DEBUG -DUNIT_TESTING -DHAVE_UNIBILIUM -D_GNU_SOURCE -DINCLUDE_GENERATED_DECLARATIONS -DUTF8PROC_STATIC -I/home/max/workspace/github.com/neovim/neovim.git/.deps/usr/include/luajit-2.1 -I/home/max/workspace/github.com/neovim/neovim.git/.deps/usr/include -I/home/max/workspace/github.com/neovim/neovim.git/build/src/nvim/auto -I/home/max/workspace/github.com/neovim/neovim.git/build/include -I/home/max/workspace/github.com/neovim/neovim.git/build/cmake.config -I/home/max/workspace/github.com/neovim/neovim.git/src -I/usr/include

   system vimrc file: "$VIM/sysinit.vim"
  fall-back for $VIM: "/usr/local/share/nvim"

Run :checkhealth for more info
```

### Steps to reproduce

On my machine all I need to do is:

```sh
$ MANPAGER="nvim --clean --noplugin -" man man
```
and it crashes every time

### Expected behavior

Neovim should open the man page

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.11.0-dev-714+g220b8aa6f

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no

### Operating system/version

Debian GNU/Linux 12 (bookworm)

### Terminal name/version

urxvt,gnome-terminal

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

build from source

comment_data.body:
[debug.strace.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16882417/debug.strace.txt)
I attached the strace so you can see all the files it tried opening

Did you try `MANPAGER='nvim +Man!'` as recommended in `:help :Man` ?

> ```
> # this works perfect!
> $ MANPAGER=cat man man | nvim --clean --noplugin -
> ```

Does that really work "perfectly"? If you pipe in raw man page data to `nvim -`, it won't set `filetype=man`, you will need to run `:Man!` to activate the manpage plugin. (Also `--noplugin` is ignored because it's overridden by `--clean`.)

> E903: Process failed to start: permission denied: "/usr/local/bin/nvim" Failed to start Nvim server!

`E903` comes from the `channel_job_start` call in `ui_client_start_server`. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/b6e350a6b4df40fcc99931c460668c36fadc9989/src/nvim/main.c#L344-L346

There is apparently a permissions issue with `/usr/local/bin/nvim`, or some related resource.

> Did you try `MANPAGER='nvim +Man!'` as recommended in `:help :Man` ?
> 

Yes.  That is how I first noticed the bug.  I wanted to show `nvim --clean` as an even simpler repro.  The crash happens no matter how I invoke nvim in `MANPAGER`

> Does that really work "perfectly"?

Yeah, all the formatting is messed up.  What I mean is that neovim doesn't crash.  The formatting would be fixed with `nvim +Man!`

> `E903` comes from the `channel_job_start` call in `ui_client_start_server`.  There is apparently a permissions issue

Yeah, I found that too.  I attached the `strace` so that maybe we can find where the problem is.  I tried looking through the strace but didn't see much.


The only EACCESS I saw was

```strace
[pid 28258] write(1, "rs1]u\n.3rlns m\n.3rvpt 1\n.sp |\\n["..., 4096 <unfinished ...>
[pid 28257] write(1, " page, but do print the location"..., 4096 <unfinished ...>
[pid 28261] socketpair(AF_UNIX, SOCK_STREAM|SOCK_CLOEXEC, 0,  <unfinished ...>
[pid 28259] wait4(-1,  <unfinished ...>
[pid 28258] <... write resumed>)        = 4096
[pid 28259] <... wait4 resumed>0x7ffe94a1ad0c, WNOHANG, NULL) = -1 ECHILD (No child processes)
[pid 28257] <... write resumed>)        = 4096
[pid 28261] <... socketpair resumed>0x7ffd268689b0) = -1 EACCES (Permission denied)
[pid 28257] read(0,  <unfinished ...>
[pid 28261] openat(AT_FDCWD, "/home/max/.local/state/nvim/log", O_WRONLY|O_CREAT|O_APPEND, 0666 <unfinished ...>
[pid 28258] read(0,  <unfinished ...>
```

> socketpair resumed>0x7ffd268689b0) = -1 EACCES (Permission denied

that looks relevant

does `:edit $NVIM_LOG_FILE` show anything? (by default it's shared by all Nvims so messages from the "crashed" instance will show up there. if you can get the PID, then you can match that to the log messages)

can you try this to rule out any environment variables that may be interacting:

    env -i TERM=ansi-256color MANPAGER="$(which nvim) -" man man

> does :edit $NVIM_LOG_FILE show anything?

For some reason when I launch my release nvim, I don't get any logs.  I do see logs for my debug nvim.  The behavior of `man` is the same for both, so I'll show the logs for the debug build.

These are the logs I get when running

```sh
env -i TERM=ansi-256color MANPAGER="build/bin/nvim -" man man
```

```log
INF 2024-09-05T10:20:02.788 ?.15564    libuv_process_spawn:93: uv_spawn(/home/max/workspace/github.com/neovim/neovim/build/bin/nvim) failed: permission denied
INF 2024-09-05T10:20:02.788 ?.15564    emsg_multiline:717: E903: Process failed to start: permission denied: "/home/max/workspace/github.com/neovim/neovim/build/bin/nvim"
INF 2024-09-05T10:20:02.789 ?.15564    os_exit:695: Nvim exit: 1
```


```sh
$ ls -l build/bin/nvim
-rwxr-xr-x 1 max max 18036112 Sep  5 10:17 build/bin/nvim
```

Now that I see the error is in `libuv_process_spawn:93`, I can put logs around the error.

```diff
diff --git a/src/nvim/event/libuv_process.c b/src/nvim/event/libuv_process.c
--- a/src/nvim/event/libuv_process.c
+++ b/src/nvim/event/libuv_process.c
@@ -89,7 +89,9 @@
   }
 
   int status;
+  fprintf(stderr, "@@@ before");
   if ((status = uv_spawn(&proc->loop->uv, &uvproc->uv, &uvproc->uvopts))) {
+    fprintf(stderr, "@@@ after");
     ILOG("uv_spawn(%s) failed: %s", uvproc->uvopts.file, uv_strerror(status));
     if (uvproc->uvopts.env) {
       os_free_fullenv(uvproc->uvopts.env);
```

This helps narrow the strace:

```strace
[pid 20084] brk(NULL <unfinished ...>
[pid 20088] write(2, "@@@ before", 10@@@ before <unfinished ...>
[pid 20091] newfstatat(AT_FDCWD, "/home/max/.cargo/bin/locale",  <unfinished ...>
[pid 20085] <... munmap resumed>)       = 0
[pid 20084] <... brk resumed>)          = 0x5f15ae2ae000
[pid 20091] <... newfstatat resumed>0x7ffcceab5840, 0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
[pid 20088] <... write resumed>)        = 10
[pid 20091] newfstatat(AT_FDCWD, "/home/max/.local/share/umake/bin/locale",  <unfinished ...>
[pid 20084] brk(0x5f15ae2cf000 <unfinished ...>
[pid 20091] <... newfstatat resumed>0x7ffcceab5840, 0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
[pid 20088] socketpair(AF_UNIX, SOCK_STREAM|SOCK_CLOEXEC, 0,  <unfinished ...>
[pid 20085] getrandom( <unfinished ...>
[pid 20091] newfstatat(AT_FDCWD, "/usr/local/bin/locale",  <unfinished ...>
[pid 20084] <... brk resumed>)          = 0x5f15ae2cf000
[pid 20091] <... newfstatat resumed>0x7ffcceab5840, 0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
[pid 20088] <... socketpair resumed>0x7fffd0618080) = -1 EACCES (Permission denied)
[pid 20085] <... getrandom resumed>"\x85\x27\x97\x7a\x2f\xe0\x21\x5b", 8, GRND_NONBLOCK) = 8
[pid 20091] newfstatat(AT_FDCWD, "/usr/bin/locale",  <unfinished ...>
[pid 20088] write(2, "@@@ after", 9@@@ after <unfinished ...>
[pid 20091] <... newfstatat resumed>{st_mode=S_IFREG|0755, st_size=47272, ...}, 0) = 0
```

This further points the culprit at the `socketpair`

does your system have some sort of `ulimit` restriction or SELinux/AppArmor/etc hardening? Failing `socketpair` is not something we have encountered before :) We pretty much expect that it's always possible to spawn a child process and open an anonymous two-way pipe to it.


Can you confirm if this issue is present on an older version (don't need to build from source, [downloads are here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases)) (may be worth checking as far back as 8.x)

@justinmk here's another doozy:

```sh
$ sudo cp -v /usr/bin/man{,.bkp}
'/usr/bin/man' -> '/usr/bin/man.bkp'

$ MANPAGER="./build/bin/nvim --clean -" /usr/bin/man man
E903: Process failed to start: permission denied: "/home/max/workspace/github.com/neovim/neovim/build/bin/nvim"Failed to start Nvim server!
/usr/bin/man: command exited with status 1: sed -e '/^[[:space:]]*$/{ N; /^[[:space:]]*\n[[:space:]]*$/D; }' | LESS=-ix8RmPm Manual page man(1) ?ltline %lt?L/%L.:byte %bB?s/%s..?e (END):?pB %pB\%.. (press h for help or q to quit)$PM Manual page man(1) ?ltline %lt?L/%L.:byte %bB?s/%s..?e (END):?pB %pB\%.. (press h for help or q to quit)$ MAN_PN=man(1) ./build/bin/nvim --clean -

$ MANPAGER="./build/bin/nvim --clean -" /usr/bin/man.bkp man
# works perfectly!
```

> Can you confirm if this issue is present on an older version (don't need to build from source, [downloads are here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases)) (may be worth checking as far back as 8.x)

```sh
$ MANPAGER="$HOME/Downloads/nvim-linux64-nightly/bin/nvim --clean -" /usr/bin/man man
E903: Process failed to start: permission denied: "/home/max/Downloads/nvim-linux64-nightly/bin/nvim"Failed to start Nvim server!
/usr/bin/man: command exited with status 1: sed -e '/^[[:space:]]*$/{ N; /^[[:space:]]*\n[[:space:]]*$/D; }' | LESS=-ix8RmPm Manual page man(1) ?ltline %lt?L/%L.:byte %bB?s/%s..?e (END):?pB %pB\%.. (press h for help or q to quit)$PM Manual page man(1) ?ltline %lt?L/%L.:byte %bB?s/%s..?e (END):?pB %pB\%.. (press h for help or q to quit)$ MAN_PN=man(1) /home/max/Downloads/nvim-linux64-nightly/bin/nvim --clean -

$ MANPAGER="$HOME/Downloads/nvim-linux64-0.8.3/bin/nvim --clean -" /usr/bin/man man
# works perfectly!
```

> ```shell
> $ sudo cp -v /usr/bin/man{,.bkp}
> '/usr/bin/man' -> '/usr/bin/man.bkp'
> 
> $ MANPAGER="./build/bin/nvim --clean -" /usr/bin/man man
> E903: ...
> 
> $ MANPAGER="./build/bin/nvim --clean -" /usr/bin/man.bkp man
> # works perfectly!
> ```

So copying `/usr/bin/man` to a different path works? And you showed that it works with you pipe from other programs, e.g. `cat foo | nvim -`. ~~And you repro'd on Nvim 0.8.x, so this is not a recent regression.~~

So it seems like `/usr/bin/man` is doing something specifically that breaks the environment, apparently only if `argv[0]="man"`.

> And you repro'd on Nvim 0.8.x, so this is not a recent regression.

I didn't repro on 0.8.x.  Here https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/30268#issuecomment-2332547367 I showed that it doesn't work on nightly but does work 0.8.3

@justinmk I bisected and was able to narrow it down to either

24488169564c39a506c235bf6a33b8e23a8cb528 or
43e8ec92de9e0850e7d202cb7ff9051bc408447e

(24488169564c39a506c235bf6a33b8e23a8cb528 failed to compile, so I skipped it)

repro:

```sh
$ MANPAGER="./build/bin/nvim --clean - +q\!" git bisect run sh -c "make -j distclean || exit 420 && make -j || exit 4269 && man man"

> I bisected and was able to narrow it down to either https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/24488169564c39a506c235bf6a33b8e23a8cb528 or https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/43e8ec92de9e0850e7d202cb7ff9051bc408447e

Thanks for confirming/bisecting. Before those commits, Nvim's "ui client" was an internal thread, instead of a co-process.

So we're still stuck at the question of what is preventing the child stream from being created on your system.
This smells like a sandboxing issue. Do you get anything interesting in `sudo dmesg`/`sudo journalctl -xe`? (I'm hoping for apparmor failures.)

> This smells like a sandboxing issue. Do you get anything interesting in `sudo dmesg`/`sudo journalctl -xe`? (I'm hoping for apparmor failures.)

ding ding ding 🛎️

```log
[14046.478013] audit: type=1400 audit(1725657674.226:434): apparmor="DENIED" operation="capable" class="cap" profile="/usr/bin/man" pid=16524 comm="nvim" capability=21  capname="sys_admin"

[14046.479007] audit: type=1400 audit(1725657674.227:435): apparmor="DENIED" operation="create" class="net" info="failed type and protocol match" error=-13 profile="/usr/bin/man" pid=16524 comm="nvim" family="unix" sock_type="stream" protocol=0 requested="create" denied="create" addr=none
```



<details>
<summary>This is what I have in `/etc/apparmor.d/usr.bin.man`</summary>

```apparmor
# vim:syntax=apparmor

#include <tunables/global>

/usr/bin/man {
  #include <abstractions/base>

  # Use a special profile when man calls anything groff-related.  We only
  # include the programs that actually parse input data in a non-trivial
  # way, not wrappers such as groff and nroff, since the latter would need a
  # broader profile.
  /usr/bin/eqn rmCx -> &man_groff,
  /usr/bin/grap rmCx -> &man_groff,
  /usr/bin/pic rmCx -> &man_groff,
  /usr/bin/preconv rmCx -> &man_groff,
  /usr/bin/refer rmCx -> &man_groff,
  /usr/bin/tbl rmCx -> &man_groff,
  /usr/bin/troff rmCx -> &man_groff,
  /usr/bin/vgrind rmCx -> &man_groff,

  # Similarly, use a special profile when man calls decompressors and other
  # simple filters.
  /{,usr/}bin/bzip2 rmCx -> &man_filter,
  /{,usr/}bin/gzip rmCx -> &man_filter,
  /usr/bin/col rmCx -> &man_filter,
  /usr/bin/compress rmCx -> &man_filter,
  /usr/bin/iconv rmCx -> &man_filter,
  /usr/bin/lzip.lzip rmCx -> &man_filter,
  /usr/bin/tr rmCx -> &man_filter,
  /usr/bin/xz rmCx -> &man_filter,

  # Allow basically anything in terms of file system access, subject to DAC.
  # The purpose of this profile isn't to confine man itself (that might be
  # nice in the future, but is tricky since it's quite configurable), but to
  # confine the processes it calls that parse untrusted data.
  /** mrixwlk,
  unix,

  capability setuid,
  capability setgid,

  # Ordinary permission checks sometimes involve checking whether the
  # process has this capability, which can produce audit log messages.
  # Silence them.
  deny capability dac_override,
  deny capability dac_read_search,

  signal peer=@{profile_name},
  signal peer=/usr/bin/man//&man_groff,
  signal peer=/usr/bin/man//&man_filter,

  # Site-specific additions and overrides.  See local/README for details.
  #include <local/usr.bin.man>
}

profile man_groff {
  #include <abstractions/base>
  # Recent kernels revalidate open FDs, and there are often some still
  # open on TTYs.  This is temporary until man learns to close irrelevant
  # open FDs before execve.
  #include <abstractions/consoles>
  # man always runs its groff pipeline with the input file open on stdin,
  # so we can skip <abstractions/user-manpages>.

  /usr/bin/eqn rm,
  /usr/bin/grap rm,
  /usr/bin/pic rm,
  /usr/bin/preconv rm,
  /usr/bin/refer rm,
  /usr/bin/tbl rm,
  /usr/bin/troff rm,
  /usr/bin/vgrind rm,

  /etc/groff/** r,
  /etc/papersize r,
  /usr/lib/groff/site-tmac/** r,
  /usr/share/groff/** r,

  /tmp/groff* rw,

  signal peer=/usr/bin/man,
  # @{profile_name} doesn't seem to work here.
  signal peer=/usr/bin/man//&man_groff,
}

profile man_filter {
  #include <abstractions/base>
  # Recent kernels revalidate open FDs, and there are often some still
  # open on TTYs.  This is temporary until man learns to close irrelevant
  # open FDs before execve.
  #include <abstractions/consoles>

  /{,usr/}bin/bzip2 rm,
  /{,usr/}bin/gzip rm,
  /usr/bin/col rm,
  /usr/bin/compress rm,
  /usr/bin/iconv rm,
  /usr/bin/lzip.lzip rm,
  /usr/bin/tr rm,
  /usr/bin/xz rm,

  # Manual pages can be more or less anywhere, especially with "man -l", and
  # there's no harm in allowing wide read access here since the worst it can
  # do is feed data to the invoking man process.
  /** r,

  # Allow writing cat pages.
  /var/cache/man/** w,

  signal peer=/usr/bin/man,
  # @{profile_name} doesn't seem to work here.
  signal peer=/usr/bin/man//&man_filter,
}

```
</details>
If you find out how to configure apparmor to support this, please mention it here and we'll add to to the docs somewhere.

You should be able to use `aa-genprof` (from the apparmor-utils package) in order to generate a profile that will let `man` spawn neovim and neovim create its socket. It's been years since I last used it but I remember it being extremely user-friendly.

Hello, as an alternative to modifying the AppArmor profile for `man`, I use the following approach. My previous warnings were also caused by plugins attempting to open network sockets.

For man pages, I use a specific `init_man.lua` that has only the minimum dependencies I need: in my case these dependencies do not need to open network sockets.

Redefine `export MANPAGER='nvim -u ~/.config/nvim/init_man.lua +Man!'`

The `init_man.lua` sits next to my `init.lua` and has the bare minimum I want:

```lua
-- Global settings
require('global.settings')  -- things such as vim.opts.termguicolors, etc, common to my main config.
-- Any other settings specific to man pages
vim.opt.number = false
vim.opt.relativenumber = false
vim.opt.signcolumn = 'no'

-- Bootstrap lazy.nvim
local lazypath = vim.fn.stdpath("data") .. "/site/lazy/lazy.nvim"
---@diagnostic disable-next-line: undefined-field
if not (vim.uv or vim.loop).fs_stat(lazypath) then
  vim.fn.system({
    "git",
    "clone",
    "--filter=blob:none",
    "https://github.com/folke/lazy.nvim.git",
    "--branch=stable",
    lazypath,
  })
end
---@diagnostic disable-next-line: undefined-field
vim.opt.rtp:prepend(lazypath)

-- Configure lazy.nvim
require("lazy").setup({
  -- Your color scheme plugin
  {
    "altercation/vim-colors-solarized",
    lazy = false,
    priority = 1000,
    config = function()
      vim.o.background = "light" -- has to be reset at the of nvim startup
      vim.cmd([[colorscheme solarized]])
    end,
  },
  {
    "christoomey/vim-tmux-navigator",
    lazy = false,
    event = "VimEnter",
  },
}, {
  -- Lazy.nvim options
  install = {
    colorscheme = { "solarized" },
  },
  performance = {
    rtp = {
      disabled_plugins = {
        "gzip",
        "matchit",
        "matchparen",
        "netrwPlugin",
        "tarPlugin",
        "tohtml",
        "tutor",
        "zipPlugin",
      },
    },
    cache = {
      enabled = false,
      -- path = vim.fn.stdpath("data") .. "/site/lazy/cache/man_config",
    },
  },
})

-- Enable Man plugin
vim.cmd('runtime ftplugin/man.vim')
```

I hope it helps, or at least you find it interesting.

Cheers

> If you find out how to configure apparmor to support this, please mention it here and we'll add to to the docs somewhere.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/15590#issuecomment-2582409258 provides a hint (but it's for `fuse` , I guess a different config will be needed for `man` ?):

> On Ubuntu this is caused by AppArmor's sandboxing of man.
> 
> We can add a local override to allow it:
> 
> /etc/apparmor.d/local/usr.bin.man
> 
> ```
> mount fstype=fuse.nvim options=(ro, nosuid, nodev) -> /tmp/**,
> /usr/bin/fusermount Ux,
> ```

title: permission denied by AppArmor with `MANPAGER="nvim -" man man` (socketpair EACCES)
